petitioner.name: THE PERMANENT MISSION OF INDIA TO THE UNITED NATIONS, ET AL.

respondent.name: CITY OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument first this morning in case 06-134, The Permanent Mission of India to the United Nations et al. vs. The City of New York. Mr. Howley.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Of course you could say the same thing if the mission here sold its property to someone and someone was claiming the right to possess the property by reason of the sale. And you could come up and say this is simply, simply a case deciding the, the ultimate issue of whether the sale occurred or not.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But it would clearly come within the property right exception, wouldn't it? You -- you don't go one step back to look at the transaction that created the, the right in real property assuming the right in real property exists.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Let's assume that, let's assume that exception didn't exist.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And you had nothing but the real estate exception. You would come in and say this ultimately relates to not who owns the real estate but whether there was a proper contract or not. And I - - frankly we wouldn't accept that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But what New York is seeking is an interest in land and a lien is an interest in the land. It runs with the land, doesn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Can't he force a sale of the property to collect the lien?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I understand that this action does not because of the sovereign immunity. But -- but we are talking about what the nature of a lien is. In an ordinary case cannot a lien holder force a sale of the property so that he can get out the money represented by his lien?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, how can he commence an action to foreclose on the property unless he in any ordinary sense of the term has an interest in the property?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You're distinguishing between rights in property and interests in property? I would think that every right in property is an interest in property and vice versa.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: The counterclaim sounds to me very much like it comes straight out of the Federal Rules, not out of any convention. It's the same transaction and occurrence, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, that's exactly what it says in the Federal Rules about compulsory - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Congress didn't really say it. I mean the committee said it to be precise.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Good.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What was your distinction between a mortgage and a tax lien?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, so think they can't enforce mortgage under this? That is to say the bank can't; it's not an interest of property in mortgage?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: That's, that's where it's hard for me because a purchase money mortgage, you sell the real estate. Ordinary secured interest in mortgage is secured interest by a lender is normally viewed as an interest in property, I think. I mean is there, is there any law anywhere that says that isn't an interest in property?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, on that point in some jurisdictions and perhaps you can tell me about New York, I had thought and correct me if I'm wrong, that tax liens have a superior status to other liens in that they are an, an interest or an estate in the property as opposed to an attachment. Is it not true? And I don't, and I'm not talking just about order of priority for creditors. I'm talking about the superiority insofar as being or not being an interest in property.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Is there New York law to that effect?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Because I had -- I had thought that it is an estate in land in at least some jurisdictions. And Justice Breyer was asking about the same thing. In other words, there are liens -- there are liens and liens. There are different kinds of liens.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, that brings up the basic question I have, is this a question of State law or Federal law?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So even if you have different rules in different States, there is going to be one rule under Federal law under 1605(a)(4)?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Had the State Department taken a position at that point, at the time the Act was passed?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: There was nothing vague about the State Department's brief in the Englewood case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But anyway, at a time closer to the passage of the Act, the State Department was taking the position that a lien was an interest in land.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, they just may be more sympathetic to India and Mongolia than they were to Libya.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's not beyond the realm of the conceivable, is it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But I take it there has never been a case in the history of the world you'll tell me where a lender or bank or anybody who loaned money to build an embassy has ever brought a case against the owner of the embassy, the sovereign, and won under anything like this exception, because they can't sue them.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Ever. And there is none the other way, where they said you couldn't sue them.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Okay. So why do people lend money to build embassies?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And how did it work before 1605 was passed, how did they used to build, in the 19th century, embassies, if you know.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Why isn't buying land that you're not using for your embassy itself, or for the residence of the ambassador, but buying and occupying that land which subjects yourself to real estate taxes on that land, why isn't that a commercial activity?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So the Indian embassy could own real estate throughout New York City, which it wouldn't have to pay taxes on? Or if it didn't, nothing could be done about it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Why? No. You're saying, you're saying it's not a commercial activity. I mean - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It depends upon the use, and the use in this case is not -- is not the embassy itself or the residence of the ambassador. I mean, they could use a piece of property for anything.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But the buying and occupying of it is commercial activity.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Why isn't it commercial activity for New York to say, we provide garbage services, electric services, et cetera.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But they pay fees and New York taxes. Suppose New York doesn't have fees. Suppose they say, we'll just do this out of our property tax.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And in reality, you will never get there, because the Vienna Convention deals with the substantive liability -- you're talking about jurisdiction. On your theory, you would never get to the fee for picking up the garbage, because you wouldn't have any jurisdiction.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: The commercial activity, it's applied to that same building that you say can't be -- it can't be any suit for taxes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Even -- even if this, the building were only the mission and the representative, the minister to the U.N., even then - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- the water of a municipal service, garbage collection, could be charged.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, it's the city. Not a private company, the city itself.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Of course, this isn't a suit for the taxes. I mean, we are not talking about a suit for the taxes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: We are talking about a declaration as to the interest in the land.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: You could easily say there has to be a relationship to the property itself.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Howley. Mr. Srinivasan.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's always brought up to answer the problem, well, you know -- let me give you a case in which it obviously is not a commercial activity, but it seems to me that the -- that the lien interest has to be honored. Let's suppose that there is an American who is very friendly to and sympathetic with the Indian government, and gives them real estate, not a commercial activity, he gives them real estate in which to house the employees in -- in their mission. However, he retains an interest in that real estate. He retains a lien on the real estate, to have money paid to him at some point. He is not willing to give the full amount of the property, but most of it. And he retains a lien. Now, under your theory, that lien would not be enforceable, is that right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Enforceable or not.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That seems very strange to me.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I thought that the Department submitted a good brief on this issue, but in What do you do with all the arguments -- I'm looking at page 12 of your brief in the Englewood case, which you argued that these liens were interests in property. Are those arguments no longer valid?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, what about the argument that it was an interest in property. The brief was very clear that it is an interest in property, and that a tax lien is almost sui generis, in that it is an estate in the property.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: It survives bona fide - - it survives bona fide purchaser without notice?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: The other reasons you gave, the holder of a lien can bring an action to enjoin waste, holders of liens are entitled to compensation if eminent domain is exercised. All of those reasons are still as valid as they were in 1985.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What property is it a right in if not the immovable property?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And it follows that immovable property and when the immovable property disappears the lien disappears. You know, if it's blown away or flooded, it's now in the Atlantic; the lien is gone.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, how can the, how can the lien holder then bring an action to enjoin waste of the immovable property?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What about paragraph 3 just after paragraph 2 in the complaint? Paragraph 3 asks the court to bar and forever foreclose the defendants from all right, interest, claim, etcetera in the parcel. Well, what about that? What they're asking, I just heard it. So what's the answer to that? They seem to be saying, we have the right to the parcel, you the defendant have no right to the parcel.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, I did in part, so he can answer.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: In a very practical way, you're expressing that right means ownership means ownership. But the title is certainly impaired by this lien. India could not turn around and sell it to anyone without doing something to discharge the, lien right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So the title is certainly clouded by this lien.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It doesn't have to be a right in the property. If you look at it from the owner's point of view, it is a cloud on the owner's title in the property. It affects the owner's title. Even if you assert that it doesn't give any title to the lien holder, it impairs the title of the property owner. And that's all that's required, as I read the title, in which rights in immovable property are an issue, and here the question is whether the, the mission's right to the property is, is impaired by this lien.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It affects the right to convey the property free and clear, which is an enormous right that goes along with the real estate.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: How long did the United States take the opposite position and when did it change?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: How long did the United States adhere to the position that's reflect in the Englewood brief and when did it change?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What about an easement? That doesn't involve any of those things. You can't exclude people and so forth.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Counsel. Mr. Cardozo.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Mr. Cardozo, before you go any further, I had been under the impression from your brief that you're not trying to enforce anything against, against India or against the mission. You just said you wanted a declaratory judgment that the lien is a valid lien. But, but here it is in your complaint you're asking for foreclosure. Which, which is it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You just asked for it to scare them? Was that it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, but they'll say as was their response to a lot of hypotheticals, the commercial act exception covers that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: The problem that actually is bothering me with your side of the case which I find difficult is, suppose I accept this principle that you have. All right, it seems to me anything at all can be reduced to a lien, any judgment, at least certainly slip and fall cases and you didn't keep the ice up in front and I want $4 million damages plus 300 million in punitives and where it is I have a lien against the embassy here. And I can't think of a distinction once I go down your road. I mean, he at least has an absolute distinction which I can see, but once I go down your road where is the stopping place? What's the principle?

speakers.name: MR. ROBERTS
speakers.text: Let me try, Justice Breyer. First of all, if there was a judgment on that hypothetical tort action that you just mentioned, if there were a judgment you wouldn't have gotten the judgment in the first place unless you had originally come within - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I'm imagining a city or Belarus or someplace where what they do is they say slip and fall on ice -- you know, you get a lien against the property prior to -- okay. I mean, it's easy to imagine that kind of thing.

speakers.name: MR. ROBERTS
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And in a range of subject matters. So I'm looking to what the stopping place is once I start down your road.

speakers.name: MR. ROBERTS
speakers.text: And the stopping place I think is a Federalism concept and a due process concept, because as this Court has held in a number of cases, there's a real due process question if liens are created with no concern about the effect on the defendant. You have to take a look at the interest of the so-called plaintiff and you have to find whether there is a relationship between the lien and the underlying claim. Now - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Why didn't you just say - - you know, if you're worried about the malevolence of countries to make all sorts of stuff liens, I guess if they're malevolent enough they can make all sorts of stuff easements, which, which the other side says is undoubtedly a property interest. So they could say that, you know, if you're held liable the court can give you an easement over the property of, of the defendant worth so much money. And that would undoubtedly be enforceable.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I still have my question because I'm not world about malevolence, is that I don't carry around in my head all of the possible things that might be liens against property. And so maybe my imagination is wrong, but I want to know are you are arguing that every lien against the property is in fact a right in property which allows a lawsuit, or are you arguing that there is some distinction between some and the other. And I noticed that the Restatements and others are trying to distinguish between whether the lien in question grows out of the property or it doesn't grow out of the property, which I find possibly hard to work with and so I want to know how you see it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, let's take the parking ticket that your colleague raised, that New York would make a parking ticket a lien, unpaid parking ticket a lien on all, all property.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Yes, yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: So the only thing they would have to do I suppose -- you've mentioned the due process point -- would be to perhaps give a hearing before the lien was declared and that would be enough?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, provided that, provided notice of hearing was offered, the parking ticket lien would be in the same position as this lien, right -- the hearing.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And under New York law does property, do property tax liens have some superior status? Are they distinct under New York law from other liens?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Without reference to priority.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I -- I had thought they had a greater priority and that they even survived purchase from bona fide sellers.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: May I ask -- may I ask this question? Suppose another jurisdiction had a tax system which was just a little different from New York's and didn't provide for a lien until after a suit had been brought and there had been a failure to pay or had to get a judgment first. On that case, that jurisdiction could not enforce this tax law?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: And don't you think it's sort of a strange way to define a tax immunity, by - - by, by describing the -- the interest in immovable property?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But, but the basic issue in final analysis is whether they have to pay their taxes, isn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: The ultimate issue is whether they have to pay their taxes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Do you know any States that don't? Isn't it fairly standard? For - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yeah.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: May, may I just ask, for a kind of a footnote kind of question? I mean you referred again to the text. And if we are going to go on a very strict reading of the text as I understand it, you don't have to claim a right in property, you have to have a claim in -- in which someone's rights in immovable property are in issue. So whether the, the - - and so long as you create a cloud on the title, however that cloud is classified, it puts in issue the title of the named title holder, so that the debates about the distinction between a lien and easement and so forth is essentially irrelevant as long as it's a cloud on the title. If we are going to be that, if we are going to be literal, isn't that so?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Yeah.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: The -- the -- the European, the European treaty looks at it from the other side, you're saying. It looks at it from the foreign sovereign side.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Would the obligations arising out of the property in the European Convention include the obligation to pay taxes, property taxes?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: This says what explicitly?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Over tax liens or claims?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: And you don't go that far.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Is this the Vienna Convention?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: European Convention.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, the -- the convention used language quite different than that was used by Congress. So I'm not quite sure how that international practice reflected in or arising out of the convention is terribly pertinent.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: And in some cases they used language directly from the convention and in this case they didn't so it seems to me a particularly ill-advised source for looking for what they were trying to do.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Did their practice draw a distinction between occupied by the ambassador himself and property occupied by employees of the embassy?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Can I ask you what, what do you get out of this case? You've withdrawn your claim for judgment of foreclosure. What are you going to get out of it? Declaratory judgment that they owe the taxes? I'm not sure they have ever contested that they don't owe taxes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yeah, but - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You say he is wrong about a lot of other stuff. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Why do you believe him about that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Can I -- can I can ask you to go back for a second to where I'm getting myself into a muddle here. I'm still now being very, very literal. I think you're very literal and you say it says, a case in which is involved rights to property. And you say, but this is a right to property in this case; if I win this case then I have a right to sell that house. Therefore, I have a right in property. Now, if that's the reasoning why doesn't that apply to every case where a State might say if you win this case you can sell his house? I mean, I can easily imagine a tort case, a contract case where a State would say, you win, you can sell their house to collect the judgment.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So I'm still back in a different route at where I'm having the problem, which is a problem of distinguishing in principle between either your absolute principle, "do it," his absolute principle, "don't do it," or something in the middle.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: The hypothetical was doing away with the prejudgment lien. I would say the exact same words apply with just as much force if there is no prejudgment lien because a suit without a lien the State were to say, you win this tort claim, you can go sell this property to collect the judgment, is a suit in which there is at issue your right to sell his property, just as there is here.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Do you?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, wait a minute. But the -- the embassy has rights in it when the case is brought, even before the final judgment. So you know, let's give the devil his due. It would be a case in which rights in immovable property are in issue.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You want to look at it from the embassy side too so - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, that's your big defense. To do that they would have to do it for everybody' they would have to do it for Joe Sixpack as well as for the embassy, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Is it only the case that the, that the only instances in which, consistent with the Foreign Sovereign Immunities Act the State could say you get the house, would be instances of litigation arising out of commercial activity?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Yeah.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Now -- now I take it you under New York law and the law of most jurisdictions, the tax lien becomes a lien against the property before any judicial proceedings.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Just because they are unpaid. And this is probably a question more for them than for you, but as you understand their position, if you put a lien on the property for unpaid taxes, are they entitled to demand its removal?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: You mean of course they can under their view?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: No. No. No.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEY
speakers.text: Excuse me.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Can they demand that that lien be released - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: No, no. -- because it violates the Foreign Sovereign Immunities Act? Is it their position that you have no right at all even to notice a lien against the property?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: It would seem to me to follow from what they're saying.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: My hypothetical is can they demand that the lien be removed solely because of the Foreign Sovereign Immunities Act.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: With reference to the offset of foreign aid, could that offset be made under the controlling statutes just based on your lien, or do you have to have a judgment first?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: May I ask you a question in your remaining time. With respect to the statute that authorizes the, the charge against foreign aid, would that statute have any application except either in a commercial case or a case like yours?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: That's right. You can go directly.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: So in practical terms, with the possible exception of a counterclaim, the foreign aid setoff would simply apply to a case like this, then?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: I was going to say, if you deny all the statutes you've got to - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What do you do with traffic tickets? They've built up. You know, there's $100,000 owing in traffic tickets by some embassy. How do you get a judgment that that is owing?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So you can't use even the foreign aid gimmick to - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Foreign aid - -

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Unless New York law is changed and you pass something saying you get a lien on property if you have delinquent property, parking tickets.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I thought that the Federal, the 100 percent withholding, relates to taxes?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Taxes, not for parking tickets or anything else.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Counsel. Mr. Howley, you have two minutes remaining.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Do you take the position that it's improper even to notice the property with the lien?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I mean, let's assume that you owe the taxes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You mean we'll have to start paying our taxes around the world?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Is that a real problem for us? I don't think so.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Counsel. The case is submitted. [Whereupon, at 11:01 a.m., the case in the above-entitled matter was submitted.]
